column4: Hey all, I need a good ftp client, recently I've used gFTP but I don't really like it so much and it's not that stable
What do you use?
ftp
How about using FTP at the command line?
It's quick and easy.
Well I'm not sure
I rather use a GUI one to start with, it's easier when I work
Or, you can use the built-in "Connect to Server..." that lets you access FTP shares as part of the Gnome virtual file system.
Places -> Connect to Server...
choose Public FTP, put in your login, and it should come right up.
My point is that, while I'm sure you can find some neat FTP programs out there, Ubuntu has a lot of FTP functionality built in.
I understand, I'll try that out, right away
They ask me for a keyring?
If it says to give a default password for a keyring, then just put in something memorable.
Why should I use public ftp? Then it only tries to connect anonymously, so I couldn't enter my usr and pwd
If you don't want to connect publicly, use the FTP (with login) option.
I CAN'T connect publicly. But with this virtual drive I can't open a file on the fly and edit
But I suppose that's normal since it's still FTP
Some programs, ones that have built-in support for Gnome VFS, will be able to edit "on the fly" as you say, without having to download, edit, and upload.
Other programs don't have that support, but you might be able to find it in a plugin or patch if it's important to your workflow.
Ah okay, thanks
